lesson.title: Phase 1: Understand
lesson.summary: This lesson covers the first phase of the Design Sprint -- Understanding. You'll get an overview of this phase, and learn several methods to increase understanding

atoms.title: UNDERSTAND Heading
atoms.text: # Phase 1: Understand

atoms.title: Phase 1 Image
atoms.caption: Phase 1 of the Design Sprint: Understand
atoms.alt: Understand is phase 1 of the Design Sprint

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
The first phase of the Design Sprint is **Understand**. The goal with this phase is to create a shared understanding of the problem space across all sprint team members. There are a number of different ways that this understanding can be captured and shared, but we’ll focus on just a few in this course.

You’ll want to set up inputs that highlight and demonstrate different viewpoints and perspectives across a multitude of dimensions. You can do this using the following techniques:

- Lightning talks
 - User research
 - Business goals/needs
 - Technology
 - and more
- Interviews
 - User interviews
 - Stakeholder interviews
 - Expert interviews
- Competitive analysis

You’ll guide the team through responding to these inputs and capturing their responses through the following methods:
- How Might We
- Rose Bud Thorn
- Affinity Mapping
- and more

atoms.title: Topics & Learning Objectives
atoms.text:
# Topics and Learning Objectives

In this lesson, we’ll cover the following topics:
- The Understand phase of the Design sprint
- Creating inputs to get a deeper understanding
- Responding to inputs through design thinking methods
 - How Might We
 - Rose Bud Thorn
- Identifying themes and related ideas through affinity mapping

At the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to:
- Describe the Understand phase of the Design Sprint
- Describe how lightning talks can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Describe how interviews can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Describe how competitive analysis can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Use the “How Might We” method to identify opportunities
- Use the “Rose Thorn Bud” method to classify things as positive, negative, or opportunities
- Use Affinity Mapping to identify thematic insights

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
## Glossary

Here are some of the terms we will be covering in this lesson:


| Term | Definition |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Lightning Talk  | A short presentation focused on a specific topic |
| How Might We | A method to frame problems as solutions |
| Rose, Bud, Thorn | A method to visually classify aspects of a topic as being positive, an opportunity, or negative | 
| Affinity Mapping |  A  method to sort ideas and insights into themes |

atoms.title: Input Header
atoms.text: ## Inputs

atoms.title: Lightning Talk Summary
atoms.text:
## Lightning Talk

A lightning talk is a short presentation, usually about 20 minutes, focused on a specific topic.

* **User research**

  * Who is the user?
  * What are their needs and goals?
  * Why does this problem matter to users?

* **Business goals**
  * What are we trying to solve?
  * Why does it matter?
  * What have we tried in the past?
  * What’s worked well and not so well?

* **Technology**
  * What are our technical capabilities?
  * What are the limits and constraints or limitations on our existing tech?

atoms.title: Summary - Interviews
atoms.text:
## Interviews  

Interviews allow you to gain perspectives from a number of different vantage points.  There are lots of types of interviews you can set up including:

* **User interviews**
  * Build empathy for users
  * Get a deeper understanding of user needs and pain points

* **Stakeholder interviews**
  * Dive deeper into some of the reasoning, rationale, and context of why this specific problem is important to solve
  * Topics can include any previous efforts to solve this or a similar problem

* **Expert interviews**
  * Provide specialized insights around a specific problem, population, or technology
  * Can be either internal or external

atoms.title: Summary Competitive Analysis
atoms.text:
## Competitive Analysis

Get a better understanding of the competition and other solutions that exist in the problem space by:

* Doing research, including checking out websites and press materials

* Reading reviews 

* Using the product and recording your experience


### Keep in mind…

*Just because a competitor built something a certain way doesn’t mean it was the right thing to build or that it was built the right way.*

atoms.title: Expanding the Team's Understanding
atoms.text:
## Exercise: Expanding the Team's Understanding

The Design Sprint team for the Grocery Store Chain wants to learn more about increased competition from online delivery services.  Let's create a plan to help the team get a better understanding of the problem.

atoms.title: Who Should Give a Lightning Talk?

question.title: Tell us what topics you want to learn more about and where you'd find someone to speak about that topic
question.text: Who would you invite to speak to the team and what would you ask them to talk about?

answer.text: Thanks for your response.  I'll share my thoughts in the next video

question.title: Tell us which types of interviews you would conduct and what you expect to learn from each type
question.text: Who should the team interview?  What do you expect to learn from each interviewee?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. I'll share my thoughts in the next video

atoms.title: How will you Research the Competition?

question.title: Tell us what you'll do to learn more about your competitors
question.text: What types of competitive research will you conduct?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. I'll share my thoughts in the next video

atoms.title: Exercise Solution
atoms.text: ## Solution: Expanding the Team's Understanding

atoms.title: Input Summary
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember

*  **Lightning talks** are short presentations, usually about 20 minutes, focused on a specific topic.
* **Interviews** allow you to gain perspectives from a number of different vantage points.
* **Competitive Analysis** helps you understand other solutions or ideas that might exist in this space


Lightning talks, interviews, and competitive research provide helpful inputs for expanding the team’s understanding of the problem. In the rest of the Understand Phase we'll use design thinking methods to respond to these inputs.

atoms.title: How Might We Heading
atoms.text: ## How Might We

atoms.title: Things to Remember
atoms.text:
“How Might We” is a method to capture problems and frame them as opportunities that can be solved. Each statement should be captured on its own sticky note.

“How Might We” statements always start with the same three words, which creates a positive solution oriented framing.
- **How** - acknowledges that we don’t know the answer yet but believe this problem can be solved
- **Might** - acknowledges there can be more than one solution and that we shouldn’t stop at the first idea. “Might” also acknowledges that not every solution will work, but it’s still ok to discuss and explore ideas that might not pan out
- **We** - acknowledges that the team is invested in solving this problem together

## Things to Remember
- Write one “How Might We” statement per sticky note
- Each statement should be open ended
- Statements should focus on open ended opportunities, rather than a specific solution. Try to avoid statements that are too narrow.

answers.text: As many ideas as will fit

atoms.title: How Might We Gotchas
atoms.caption: Watch out for these common gotchas when writing “how might we” statements
atoms.alt: Make sure to phrase as a question. How might we statements should support multiple solutions, but not be too broad

question.prompt: Select examples of good "How Might We" statements

answers.text: How Might We reduce the amount of time it takes for a customer to receive their order?
How might we re-imagine the security screening experience at airports?
How might we create better gloves?
How Might We design an app to turn on and off lights?

question.title: Practice writing a “How Might We” statement
question.text: Imagine you’re working at Netflix and notice that a sizeable number of subscribers are cancelling their service in favor of other streaming services like Hulu, Amazon Prime, Video, Disney+, and AppleTV+

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Good examples could include locating interesting content, additional subscription/pricing models, social watching experiences, and interactive content.

question.title: Practice writing a “How Might We” statement
question.text: Imagine your team has been hired to help a shoe company create a better digital experience for purchasing shoes

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Good examples could include finding the perfect fit, customizing shoe design, leverage AR/VR, and make returns easy

atoms.title: Exercise:  Grocery Store Chain How Might We's
atoms.text:
## Exercise:  Grocery Store Chain "How Might We"

Think about our Grocery Store Chain's problem with increased competition from online delivery services.  Spend 15 minutes writing How Might We statements around this problem.

atoms.title: Grocery Store Chain How Might We's

question.title: Write your statements here.
question.text: Spend 15 minutes and write as many "How Might We" statements as you can

answer.text: Thanks for your response.  I'll show you some of my How Might We statements in the next video

atoms.title: L2 07 Grocery Store How Might We Solution
How Might We Summary
atoms.text:
“How Might We” is a method that allows you to reframe problems and insights into opportunities. Remember that “How Might We” statements should:
- touch on user and/or business goals/needs/problems (ideally both at the same time)
- be open ended and support multiple solutions
- not be too broad

atoms.title: How Might We Further Research
atoms.text:
## How Might We Further Research

* [How Might We](https://www.designkit.org/methods/3)
* [HMW statements](https://www.innovationchampions.com.au/toolkit/hmw-statements)

atoms.title: Rose Bud Thorn Heading
atoms.text: ## Rose, Bud, Thorn

atoms.title: ND036 C02 L02 08 Rose Bud Thorn V4
Rose Bud Thorn Intro Recap
atoms.text:
You can use the Rose, Bud, Thorn method to classify aspects of a topic and visualize good aspects, opportunities, and negative aspects.

**Roses** are positive things. For example roses could be things that are going well or seen as a successful. Roses can also represent things or parts of a product that people enjoy.

**Buds** are things that could turn into roses, if given the right attention. They represent areas of opportunity.

**Thorns** are negative things. For example thorns could be problems or shortcomings. They also can represent broken product experiences.

atoms.title: Rose Bud Thorn Example Summary
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember
- Write One thing per sticky
- Use different colored stickies for roses, buds and thorns

complex_prompt.text: Sort the Roses, Buds and Thorns

concepts.text: Messages load quickly
Lots of revenue coming from overage fees
Can't search for attachments based on contents
Undo send/edit email after sending
High app store rating

complex_prompt.text: Sort the Roses, Buds and Thorns

concepts.text: Cellular data speeds have significantly increased in the past 2 years
No message read status indicator
No spam messages make it to inbox
Easy but not always the best communication method

question.title: Roses
question.text: Think about the camera app on your phone. Identify and write at least two Roses

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Example roses could include: Camera loads and can take pictures quickly, high quality photos

question.title: Buds
question.text: Think about the camera app on your phone. Identify and write at least two Buds

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Example buds could include: More ways to edit photos after capturing and automatic album curation.

question.title: Thorns
question.text: Think about the camera app on your phone. Identify and write Thorns

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Example thorns could include: terrible shots in low light, zoom causes pixelation, lag time when taking more than 5 pictures in a short amount of time.

atoms.title: Exercise: Grocery Store Rose Bud Thorn
atoms.text: ## Exercise: Grocery Store Rose Bud Thorn

atoms.title: Rose -  Bud - Thorn for Grocery Store Chain
tasks: Gather supplies:  a pen and sticky notes (if possible get three different colors of stickies or three different pen colors)
Write at least 2 Roses on the stickies
Write at least 2 Buds on the stickies
Write at least 2 Thorns on the stickies
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice work! What have you learned?  I'll share my Roses, Buds and Thorns in the next video
atoms.description: Let's identify some  Roses, Buds and Thorns

atoms.title: Rose Bud Thorn solution
atoms.caption: Roses, Buds and Thorns for the Grocery Store
atoms.alt: Grocery Store Roses Buds and Thorns

atoms.title: Rose Bud Thorn Summary
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember
“Rose, Bud, Thorn” is a method that allows you to capture and explore positives, negatives, and opportunities within a specific topic. Ideas and reflections can be categorized as either a rose, a bud, or a thorn which represent the following:
* **Roses** are positive things or things that are going well. 
* **Buds** are things that could turn into roses, if given the right attention. They represent areas of opportunity.
* **Thorns** are negative things. For example thorns could be problems or shortcomings. They also can represent broken product experiences.

## Rose Bud Thorn Further Research

* [Rose, Thorn, Bud](https://designsprintkit.withgoogle.com/methodology/phase1-understand/rose-thorn-bud)

atoms.title: Affinity Mapping Heading
atoms.text: ## Affinity Mapping

atoms.title: ND036 C02 L02 10 Affinity Mapping V2
Affinity Mapping Recap
atoms.text: Affinity mapping is a way to visually sort related ideas together into categories and themes.You’ll go through each idea/insight, quickly discuss, and then place onto the board. As similar or related ideas are discussed their respective sticky notes should be placed next to each other. Over time you will see that **clusters** of related sticky notes have started to form. Make sure to label each cluster. Once all sticky notes have been placed on the board and you have a couple different clusters, look to see if any of those clusters are related. Related clusters will create **themes** If so, rearrange those clusters so that they are next to each other. Draw a circle around those clusters and create a label for the theme that you discovered

question.prompt: True or false: Clusters and themes are the same

complex_prompt.text: Sort the "How Might We" stickies into clusters

concepts.text: How Might We make our app faster?
How Might We reduce the number of steps users need to take?
How Might We raise awareness that our product exists?
How Might We reimagine the buy experience?
How Might We decrease delivery time?
How Might We make it easier for people to sign up?
How Might We enter a new region?
How Might We teach new users about the feature set?
Acquiring New Users
Simplify
Speed
Onboarding

atoms.title: Affinity Mapping Example Header
atoms.text:
##  Exercise: Creating an Affinity Map for the Grocery Store Chain
By this point you should have created a lot of sticky notes to help your team understand the Grocery Store Chain's problem with online shopping and delivery services. Time to sort them!

atoms.title: Grocery Store Chain Affinity Mapping
tasks: Gather all of the stickies you created in the How Might We and Rose Bud Thorn exercises
Group them into **clusters** on a flat surface that you can write on (a white board works well — or you can spread large paper on a table)
Are any **clusters** related?  If so move them closer together into a **theme** grouping
Draw a circle around each **theme** and label it
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice sorting! You can see my affinity map in the next video
atoms.description: Let's sort our stickies into groups and clusters

atoms.title: Solution: Grocery Store Affinity Mapping
atoms.text: ## Solution: Grocery Store Affinity Mapping

atoms.title: ND036 C02 L02 11 Affinity Mapping Example V2
Affinity Mapping Example Summary
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember

- It’s an interactive process. Make sure to leverage the group
- Place related sticky notes next to each other in clusters. Label each cluster with a name that represents that category
- Make sure to have an “Other” category. This is helpful if an idea doesn’t fit with other sticky notes. No need to try and force everything to fit into a category.
- Don’t be afraid to move things around. The first categories you come up with probably won’t be your final categories.
- Once all the sticky notes are on the board, check to see if any of the clusters are related. If so group them together as a theme with a label.
- Make sure to take photos, especially at the end with the completed affinity map

atoms.title: Affinity Mapping Summary
atoms.text: Affinity mapping is a method that allows you to take ideas and insights and group them into related categories and themes. This is a great way to take a large amount of information and visually represent it in a way that is much easier to parse and will inform the rest of the sprint.

## Affinity Mapping Further Research

* [HMW Sharing and Affinity Mapping](https://designsprintkit.withgoogle.com/methodology/phase1-understand/method-1)

* [A Beginner's Guide to Affinity Mapping](https://generalassemb.ly/design/user-experience-design/affinity-mapping)

* [Affinity Mapping](https://www.innovationchampions.com.au/toolkit/affinity-mapping )

* [Affinity Map Examples](http://www.syque.com/quality_tools/toolbook/Affinity/example.htm)

atoms.title: Header Text
atoms.text: ## Lesson Recap

atoms.title: Conclusion
atoms.text:
> Oops! If you were listening carefully in the video you'll hear Alex say: "It's now time to go on to Phase 3 of the Design Sprint."   He mean to say  "It's now time to go on to Phase ***2*** of the Design Sprint."   You'll get to Phase 3 -- but not quite yet. ☺


You’ve reached the end of the Phase 1: Understand lesson. We covered the following topics:
- The Understand phase of the Design sprint
- Creating inputs to get a deeper understanding
- Responding to inputs through design thinking methods
 - How Might We
 - Rose Bud Thorn
- Identifying themes and related ideas through affinity mapping

At this point, you should be able to:
- Describe the Understand phase of the Design Sprint
- Describe how lightning talks can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Describe how interviews can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Describe how competitive analysis can be used as an input during the Understand phase
- Use the “How Might We” method to identify opportunities
- Use the “Rose Thorn Bud” method to classify things as positive, negative, or opportunities
- Use Affinity Mapping to identify thematic insights
